position.marginalia_text: tam politicum, quàm militare, curiosè obseruandum: pra[e]sertim in maximis negotiis, atq[ue] bellis. Neq[ue] enim conducit Effectuum notitia potentissimorum, sine cognitione Causarum. Leguntur Historia[e], vt discatur quod est in actionibus humanis excellentissimum, pace, et bello; domi, et forìs: discitur, vt agatur: agitur optimè, non Effectuum cognitione, magnificè descripta; sed causarum scientia, intimè intellecta. Vndè aquilinis hîc oculis opus: et tam Iudicio solidissimo, quàm Ingenio solertissimo. Certè Sine acutissima Analyse, pra[e]sertim politica, et polemica, vanè leguntur Historia[e], atq[ue] frustrà. Promptissimum autem, ac pra[e]gnantissimum Romana[e] Historia[e] Prooemium, Eutropij Breuiarium; tam neruosum, atq[ue] efficax, quàm succinctum, et pressum. Qua[e] in Liuio desiderata; à Sallustio, et Ca[e]sare; à Paterculo, et Cornelio Tacito supplentur; ea né desiderantur quidem: sed ex illis continuò supplenda excellentissimis Prudentia[e], Fortitudinisq[ue] Thesauris. Adde Plutarchum: et eccé tam Gra[e]corum, quàm Romanorum preciosissima monumenta: Deus maxime, quàm egregia et axiozela? Nihil sagacius, aut profundius: etiam acria, et valida omnia. Alij etiam insignes, et pra[e]stantes Romani Historici: et in primis Polybius, Halicarnasseus, Dion, pauci alij de selectiore nota, prudentes, atq[ue] solidi scriptores: sed ista maximè necessaria; et publico, priuatoq[ue] vsui vtilissima. Nec verò vllo modo pra[e]termittendus Suetonius; propter arcana principum, et qua[e]dam Rerumpublicaru[m] secreta, dignissimus cognitu; pra[e]sertim Aulicis, et pragmaticis. Homo Liber est, vt Petrus Aretinus, et Machiauellus: nec quicq[uam] celat mysteriorum Palatinorum, et hypocriticorum. Vtilis est etiam multis egregijs exemplis Valerius Maximus: vtilissimus callidis, solidisq[ue] Stratagematis Frontinus: maximè, si illi Egnatius addatur eadem Methodo; huic, Gandinus Italicè: quorum sunt eximia pla[e]raq[ue], ac memorabilia Supplementa. Ego Romanis omnibus Historicis necessariò addendos censeo; à Politicis Machiauellum; à Iurisconsultis etiam Sigonium: et vtrisq[ue] interdum proderit Bodinus de Rep[ublica] vt bellatoribus egregiè Vegetius; cum eo, quem dixi, Frontino, et Polya[e]no. Neq[ue] enim quicq[uam] suprà, vel Latinè, vel Gra[e]cè, vel vlla Lingua hodierna: seu politicè quid agendum, seu polemicè. Interim Liuius maturimè perlegendus, et acerrimè: cuius neminem adhuc noui aut nimis studiosum historicum; aut satis obseruantem politicum. Ex ijs autem, qua[e] exstant, Liuij explicationibus, nullas malim, quàm Velcurionis annotationes historicas, et politicas: Dana[e]i aphorismos politicos: Machiauelli discursus politicos. Qui et multos illustrant reconditos locos; et rem ipsam agunt, prudentibus, serijsq[ue] obseruationib[us]. Nec dubitem tamen, ex ipsis politicorum principiorum fontibus, altiores adhuc haurire priuata[e] industria[e], publicaeq[ue] gubernationis regulas, quàm vel ab istis sunt, vel ab alijs obseruatoribus animaduersa[e]. Quomodò Aurelius Victor refert in Theodosio, Eum Imperatorem aliquando seuera pra[e]cepta habuisse de Liuio. Vt autem seriò in Romana historia proficiatur; in primis expedit, tam Eutropij, quàm Aurelij Victoris Breuiarium, semper habere promptissimum: et indè delectum facere magis exquisitum. Vt certò constabit, personas, res, actiones, omne genus negotia maximè excellere. Ea enim Euscopi tripertita prouincia. Quarta uerò; uel accurata imitatio, uel strenua a[e]mulatio. Tandem curiosè contuli Ciuitatem hominum, cum Ciuitate Dei: et mirificè placuit collatio, profuitq[ue] syncrisis, tam politica, quàm theologica. Certè axiozelus parallelismus.

marginalia.translation: The political and military "reasons why" should always both be carefully studied, especially when dealing with extremely difficult situations and wars. For acquaintance with powerful results is of no use without understanding of the causes. One reads history in order to learn what is the best in human actions in peace and in war, at home and abroad. One learns in order to act; and one acts best not as the result of understanding the outcomes, however wonderfully they are described, but through an intimate knowledge of the causes. Therefore, here one needs an eagle eye, and both a very solid judgement and an extremely skillful intellect. Really, without sharp analysis, especially political and military, reading historical accounts is vain and pointless. Now the easiest and richest introduction to Roman History is Eutropius’ Breviarium, which is as lively and effective as it is concise and compressed. What is missing in Livy is made good by Sallust and Caesar, by Velleius Paterculus and Tacitus. Indeed, things are missing, but they should be continually supplied from these outstanding storehouses of wisdom and courage. Include Plutarch, and there you have the most valuable monuments of both the Greeks and Romans - by God, how eminent and enviable! There is nothing wiser or more profound; all are penetrating and vigorous. There are also other distinguished and excellent Roman historians, in particular Polybius, Dionysius of Halicarnassus, Cassius Dio and a few others of a more exclusive reputation, judicious and solid authors, but these the most important, and most useful, both in public and private matters. Suetonius also should in no way be overlooked; he very much deserves to be studied, especially by courtiers and lawyers, for the secret affairs of emperors, and of states. Man is free, as Pietro Aretino and Macchiavelli say, and nothing hides the secrets of those on the Palatine and the pretenders. Also useful for his many superb examples is Valerius Maximus; extremely useful for his shrewd and powerful stratagems is Frontinus; and especially so if one adds to him Egnatius with the same approach, and to him Gandinus in Italian. They provide many remarkable supplementary details. I believe that the following authors should absolutely be added to all Roman historians: from the politicians, Macchiavelli; from the legal scholars, also Sigonio; and beneficial for both of these fields from time to time will be Bodin’s 'De Republica', just as Vegetius is extremely beneficial for warriors, and along with him, as I said, Frontinus and Polyaenus. And there is nothing better than these, whether in Latin, Greek or any other modern language, on how one has to act either politically or militarily. Meanwhile, Livy has to be studied as fully and shrewdly as possible. Yet, I know no current historian who studies him very deeply, nor any politician who takes sufficient notice of him. Of the existing commentaries on Livy, however, I like none better than Velcurio’s historical and political notes, Daneau’s political maxims and Machiavelli’s political discourses. These both illuminate many obscure passages, and discuss the subject-matter itself with intelligent and serious remarks. And yet I would not hesitate to derive from these sources of political principals rules regarding private industry and public government that are greater than those noted by these or other observers. As Aurelius Victor reports, the emporor Theodosius from time to time had serious thoughts about Livy. But in order to make significant progress in Roman history, it is above all useful always to keep both Eutropius’ and Aurelius Victor’s 'Breviariums' close to hand, and from there to make a more carefully considered choice, so that you can be certain to have the best examples of each kind - with regard to people, subject-matter, and deeds. For that is the threefold province of Euscopus. In fact, there is a fourth: either exact imitation, or nimble emulation. Finally, I carefully compared the city of men with 'De Civitate Dei'. The comparison was wonderfully successful and the contrast, both political and theological, very helpful. It was certainly an enviable parallel.
